subject: Communication
title: Empathy vs. Sympathy in Listening
description: A micro-lesson that makes Empathy vs. Sympathy in Listening usable.

hook.text: 'I know how you feel' (sympathy) vs. 'Help me understand how you feel' (empathy). One assumes. The other explores.

buildup.text: Sympathy is feeling for someone. Empathy is feeling with someone.

discovery.text: Bren√© Brown: sympathy drives disconnection by minimizing pain. Empathy creates connection by being present.

twist.text: Empathy doesn't mean agreeing. You can empathetically listen to someone and still disagree with their conclusion.

climax.text: Empathetic listening is rare because it's vulnerable. To truly hear someone's pain, you must be willing to feel some.

punchline.text: Sympathy says 'I'm sorry.' Empathy says 'I'm here.' One is a word.

quiz.question: What's the key difference between empathy and sympathy in listening?
options: Empathy feels with someone; sympathy feels for someone
